Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation: Development of a Maritime Adaptation in Northern Alaska: Origins of the Arctic Small Tool Tradition
Award.AbstractNarration: This project proposes to advance knowledge of the middle to early Holocene (ca. 4500-2000 cal BP) development of maritime economies along the northern coast of Alaska through an interior-coastal comparison of Arctic Small Tool tradition (ASTt) sites and assemblages. The project is a doctoral dissertation improvement grant to study maritime adaptation as it relates to the origins and spread of ASTt ca. 4500-4000 BP. This research will focus on maritime resources and coastal orientations, rather than the more traditional assumption that ASTt was a more land-based adaptation. The analysis will include artifact and faunal analysis from existing collections made at Iyatayet and Walakpa archaeological sites, as well as new excavation at Iyatayet to hopefully recover faunal material (which was not collected by Giddings). In addition, the researcher will include the participation of local Alaska Native high school students in the field excavations as part of increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in science projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The invention of technology and enhancement of knowledge necessary to extract resources from the perennially frozen arctic seas represents an adaptive process that allowed humans to colonize one of the harshest, most forbidding ecosystems on our planet. If the goal of anthropology is to understand the human condition in all times and places, and to explain the process of how this diversity came to be, then the origin of the Arctic maritime economy—and the role this system played in the colonization of this previously uninhabited niche—is a powerful case study in human adaption and diversity. 

The Arctic Small Tool tradition (ASTt) is widely recognized as the earliest culture to inhabit the high arctic of Canada and Greenland. Archaeological and genetic evidence indicate the ASTt has its origins in Siberia and its bearers were part of a migration event from Asia into Alaska and beyond beginning prior to 5000 years ago. The ASTt are also recognized as the earliest culture in northern Alaska to routinely exploit coastal resources, yet many questions persist about the extent of their maritime adaptations, when and how they were adopted, and how they changed through time.

 

Cape Espenberg Surveys (2013)

A total of 34 new archaeological sites were discovered and 21 known sites revisited during the course of foot survey at Cape Espenberg, Alaska in August, 2013. Of the sites that were tested, 11 produced radiocarbon dates ranging between 3400 and 4500 years ago, demonstrating that ASTt people camped at Cape Espenberg repeatedly for nearly 1000 years.

 

Iyatayet, Cape Denbigh, Excavations (2013)

A total of seven shovel tests and eight 1x1 meter units were excavated resulting in the recovery of 12,268 artifacts: 228 stone tools, 9836 flakes, 514 ceramic sherds, 13 osseous tools, 2 pieces of preserved leather, 4 wooden artifacts, 1534 bone fragments, 20 wood samples and 97 charcoal samples.

At the outset of this project only five ASTt sites from a coastal context in northern Alaska had been radiocarbon dated. In total our research contributed 16 new AMS dates toward refining the chronology of the Iyatayat occupations and to understanding the origin and development of coastal habitation in northern Alaska. Analysis of radiocarbon dates by ecological zone suggests ASTt peoples arrived in Alaska with maritime adaptations already established, but over time resource intensification led to further developments of this Arctic maritime economy. Analysis of hundreds of radiocarbon dates, including those produced in 2013, indicate that ASTt peoples settled coastal habitats first.

 

Broader Impacts

Archaeological research in northwest Alaska is inherently difficult and depends greatly upon the assistance of many people and organizations. This project has been a collaborative effort between the University of California, Davis, the National Park Service, the Shaktoolik Native Corporation, and most importantly, the community of Shaktoolik. Permission to work at Iyatayet was granted by the Shaktoolik Native Corporation. CEO Fred Sagoonick’s positive support was instrumental in reducing costs for the project. Funds from this project were distributed to a number of individuals in the Shaktoolik community who assisted us in this project. Three students were employed by our project as archaeological student interns. Additionally, funding was used to pay for our guide and boat transport to the site of Iyatayet. Palmer and Fena Sagoonick’s knowledge of the area and history of their ancestors at Cape Denbigh was an invaluable contribution to understanding adaptation to living in this coastal environment. While the impact of our project on the community and individuals who participated is humble, we ar...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit The invention of technology and enhancement of knowledge necessary to extract resources from the perennially frozen arctic seas represents an adaptive process that allowed humans to colonize one of the harshest, most forbidding ecosystems on our planet. If the goal of anthropology is to understand the human condition in all times and places, and to explain the process of how this diversity came to be, then the origin of the Arctic maritime economy—and the role this system played in the colonization of this previously uninhabited niche—is a powerful case study in human adaption and diversity. The Arctic Small Tool tradition (ASTt) is widely recognized as the earliest culture to inhabit the high arctic of Canada and Greenland. Archaeological and genetic evidence indicate the ASTt has its origins in Siberia and its bearers were part of a migration event from Asia into Alaska and beyond beginning prior to 5000 years ago. The ASTt are also recognized as the earliest culture in northern Alaska to routinely exploit coastal resources, yet many questions persist about the extent of their maritime adaptations, when and how they were adopted, and how they changed through time. Cape Espenberg Surveys (2013) A total of 34 new archaeological sites were discovered and 21 known sites revisited during the course of foot survey at Cape Espenberg, Alaska in August, 2013. Of the sites that were tested, 11 produced radiocarbon dates ranging between 3400 and 4500 years ago, demonstrating that ASTt people camped at Cape Espenberg repeatedly for nearly 1000 years. Iyatayet, Cape Denbigh, Excavations (2013) A total of seven shovel tests and eight 1x1 meter units were excavated resulting in the recovery of 12,268 artifacts: 228 stone tools, 9836 flakes, 514 ceramic sherds, 13 osseous tools, 2 pieces of preserved leather, 4 wooden artifacts, 1534 bone fragments, 20 wood samples and 97 charcoal samples. At the outset of this project only five ASTt sites from a coastal context in northern Alaska had been radiocarbon dated. In total our research contributed 16 new AMS dates toward refining the chronology of the Iyatayat occupations and to understanding the origin and development of coastal habitation in northern Alaska. Analysis of radiocarbon dates by ecological zone suggests ASTt peoples arrived in Alaska with maritime adaptations already established, but over time resource intensification led to further developments of this Arctic maritime economy. Analysis of hundreds of radiocarbon dates, including those produced in 2013, indicate that ASTt peoples settled coastal habitats first. Broader Impacts Archaeological research in northwest Alaska is inherently difficult and depends greatly upon the assistance of many people and organizations. This project has been a collaborative effort between the University of California, Davis, the National Park Service, the Shaktoolik Native Corporation, and most importantly, the community of Shaktoolik. Permission to work at Iyatayet was granted by the Shaktoolik Native Corporation. CEO Fred SagoonickÆs positive support was instrumental in reducing costs for the project. Funds from this project were distributed to a number of individuals in the Shaktoolik community who assisted us in this project. Three students were employed by our project as archaeological student interns. Additionally, funding was used to pay for our guide and boat transport to the site of Iyatayet. Palmer and Fena SagoonickÆs knowledge of the area and history of their ancestors at Cape Denbigh was an invaluable contribution to understanding adaptation to living in this coastal environment. While the impact of our project on the community and individuals who participated is humble, we are proud that all of our interactions were positive.
